currentDoc:
Is It Wrong to Focus on Animal Welfare When Humans Are Suffering?

Would you be surprised to hear that a study found that research subjects were more upset by stories of a dog beaten by a baseball bat than of an adult similarly beaten? Or that other researchers found that if forced to choose, 40 percent of people would save their pet dog over a foreign tourist.

Why do you think many people are more empathetic toward the suffering of animals than that of people? In your opinion, is it wrong to focus on animal welfare when humans are suffering? Why do you think so?

Why do you think many people are more empathetic toward the suffering of animals than that of people? In your opinion, is it wrong to focus on animal welfare when humans are suffering? Why do you think so?

Would you be surprised to hear that a study found that research subjects were more upset by stories of a dog beaten by a baseball bat than of an adult similarly beaten? Or that other researchers found that if forced to choose, 40 percent of people would save their pet dog over a foreign tourist.

Why do you think many people are more empathetic toward the suffering of animals than that of people? In your opinion, is it wrong to focus on animal welfare when humans are suffering? Why do you think so?

Why do you think many people are more empathetic toward the suffering of animals than that of people? In your opinion, is it wrong to focus on animal welfare when humans are suffering? Why do you think so?

Why do you think many people are more empathetic toward the suffering of animals than that of people? In your opinion, is it wrong to focus on animal welfare when humans are suffering? Why do you think so?

Is It Wrong to Focus on Animal Welfare When Humans Are Suffering?

Would you be surprised to hear that a study found that research subjects were more upset by stories of a dog beaten by a baseball bat than of an adult similarly beaten? Or that other researchers found that if forced to choose, 40 percent of people would save their pet dog over a foreign tourist.

Why do you think many people are more empathetic toward the suffering of animals than that of people? In your opinion, is it wrong to focus on animal welfare when humans are suffering? Why do you think so?

Would you be surprised to hear that a study found that research subjects were more upset by stories of a dog beaten by a baseball bat than of an adult similarly beaten? Or that other researchers found that if forced to choose, 40 percent of people would save their pet dog over a foreign tourist.

Why do you think many people are more empathetic toward the suffering of animals than that of people? In your opinion, is it wrong to focus on animal welfare when humans are suffering? Why do you think so?

---

The amount of cruelty in the world is staggering. Many millions of living things, human and animal, are made to suffer at the hands of others daily. It makes no sense to say that harm to animals is less important than harm to people, because there is no way to find a characteristic of people that makes them more important in a moral calculus than animals.

Why do you think many people are more empathetic toward the suffering of animals than that of people? In your opinion, is it wrong to focus on animal welfare when humans are suffering? Why do you think so?

Would you be surprised to hear that a study found that research subjects were more upset by stories of a dog beaten by a baseball bat than of an adult similarly beaten? Or that other researchers found that if forced to choose, 40 percent of people would save their pet dog over a foreign tourist.

Why do you think many people are more empathetic toward the suffering of animals than that of people? In your opinion, is it wrong to focus on animal welfare when humans are suffering? Why do you think so?

---

The amount of cruelty in the world is staggering. Many millions of living things, human and animal, are made to suffer at the hands of others daily. Would you be surprised to hear that a study found that research subjects were more upset by stories of a dog beaten by a baseball bat than of an adult similarly beaten? Or that other researchers found that if forced to choose, 40 percent of people would save their pet dog over a foreign tourist.

Why do you think many people are more empathetic toward the suffering of animals than that of people? In your opinion, is it wrong to focus on animal welfare when humans are suffering? Why do you think so?

Is It Wrong to Focus on Animal Welfare When Humans Are Suffering?

Would you be surprised to hear that a study found that research subjects were more upset by stories of a dog beaten by a baseball bat than of an adult similarly beaten? Or that other researchers found that if forced to choose, 40 percent of people would save their pet dog over a foreign tourist.

Why do you think many people are more empathetic toward the suffering of animals than that of people? In your opinion, is it wrong to focus on animal welfare when humans are suffering? Why do you think so?

Would you be surprised to hear that a study found that research subjects were more upset by stories of a dog beaten by a baseball bat than of an adult similarly beaten? Or that other researchers found that if forced to choose, 40 percent of people would save their pet dog over a foreign tourist.

Why do you think many people are more empathetic toward the suffering of animals than that of people? In your opinion, is it wrong to focus on animal welfare when humans are suffering? Why do you think so?

---

Is It Wrong to Focus on Animal Welfare When Humans Are Suffering?

Would you be surprised to hear that a study found that research subjects were more upset by stories of a dog beaten by a baseball bat than of an adult similarly beaten? Or that other researchers found that if forced to choose, 40 percent of people would save their pet dog over a foreign tourist.

Why do you think many people are more empathetic toward the suffering of animals than that of people? In your opinion, is it wrong to focus on animal welfare when humans are suffering? Why do you think so?

Would you be surprised to hear that a study found that research subjects were more upset by stories of a dog beaten by a baseball bat than of an adult similarly beaten? Or that other researchers found that if forced to choose, 40 percent of people would save their pet dog over a foreign tourist.

Why do you think many people are more empathetic toward the suffering of animals than that of people? In your opinion, is it wrong to focus on animal welfare when humans are suffering? Why do you think so?

---

The amount of cruelty in the world is staggering. Many millions of living things, human and animal, are made to suffer at the hands of others daily. It makes no sense to say that harm to animals is less important than harm to people, because there is no way to find a characteristic of people that makes them more important in a moral calculus than animals.

What morally-relevant characteristic do humans have that animals don't? Intelligence?  No, because some animals are smarter than some humans (e.g., a chimp has more intelligence than a newborn baby). Self-awareness? Animals are self aware. Ability to know right from wrong? M<any experiments show a moral sense in soem animal species.

Would you be surprised to hear that a study found that research subjects were more upset by stories of a dog beaten by a baseball bat than of an adult similarly beaten? Or that other researchers found that if forced to choose, 40 percent of people would save their pet dog over a foreign tourist.

Why do you think many people are more empathetic toward the suffering of animals than that of people? In your opinion, is it wrong to focus on animal welfare when humans are suffering? Why do you think so?

---

The amount of cruelty in the world is staggering. Many millions of living things, human and animal, are made to suffer at the hands of others daily. It makes no sense to say that harm to animals is less important than harm to people, because there is no way to find a characteristic of people that makes them more important in a moral calculus than animals.

What morally-relevant characteristic do humans have that animals don't? Intelligence?  No, because some animals are smarter than some humans (e.g., a chimp has more intelligence than a newborn baby). Self-awareness? Animals are self aware. Ability to know right from wrong? Many experiments show a moral sense in some animal species.

The list goes on. There is really no morally-relevant characteristic that decides what is more important: human or animal suffering.

That means a

Why do you think many people are more empathetic toward the suffering of animals than that of people? In your opinion, is it wrong to focus on animal welfare when humans are suffering? Why do you think so?

---

The amount of cruelty in the world is staggering. Many millions of living things, human and animal, are made to suffer at the hands of others daily. It makes no sense to say that harm to animals is less important than harm to people, because there is no way to find a characteristic of people that makes them more important in a moral calculus than animals.

What morally-relevant characteristic do humans have that animals don't? Intelligence?  No, because some animals are smarter than some humans (e.g., a chimp has more intelligence than a newborn baby). Self-awareness? Animals are self aware. Ability to know right from wrong? Many experiments show a moral sense in some animal species.

The list goes on. There is really no morally-relevant characteristic that decides what is more important: human or animal suffering.

That means all harm to all oliving things is

What morally-relevant characteristic do humans have that animals don't? Intelligence?  No, because some animals are smarter than some humans (e.g., a chimp has more intelligence than a newborn baby). Self-awareness? Animals are self aware. Ability to know right from wrong? Many experiments show a moral sense in some animal species.

The list goes on. There is really no morally-relevant characteristic that decides what is more important: human or animal suffering.

That means all harm to all living things is morally relevant. And people should care about both. It's no

Is It Wrong to Focus on Animal Welfare When Humans Are Suffering?

Would you be surprised to hear that a study found that research subjects were more upset by stories of a dog beaten by a baseball bat than of an adult similarly beaten? Or that other researchers found that if forced to choose, 40 percent of people would save their pet dog over a foreign tourist.

Why do you think many people are more empathetic toward the suffering of animals than that of people? In your opinion, is it wrong to focus on animal welfare when humans are suffering? Why do you think so?

The list goes on. There is really no morally-relevant characteristic that decides what is more important: human or animal suffering.

Is It Wrong to Focus on Animal Welfare When Humans Are Suffering?

Would you be surprised to hear that a study found that research subjects were more upset by stories of a dog beaten by a baseball bat than of an adult similarly beaten? Or that other researchers found that if forced to choose, 40 percent of people would save their pet dog over a foreign tourist.

Why do you think many people are more empathetic toward the suffering of animals than that of people? In your opinion, is it wrong to focus on animal welfare when humans are suffering? Why do you think so?

---

The amount of cruelty in the world is staggering. Many millions of living things, human and animal, are made to suffer at the hands of others daily. It makes no sense to say that harm to animals is less important than harm to people, because there is no way to find a characteristic of people that makes them more important in a moral calculus than animals.

What morally-relevant characteristic do humans have that animals don't? Intelligence?  No, because some animals are smarter than some humans (e.g., a chimp has more intelligence than a newborn baby). Self-awareness? Animals are self aware. Ability to know right from wrong? Many experiments show a moral sense in some animal species.

The list goes on. There is really no morally-relevant characteristic that decides what is more important: human or animal suffering.

That means all harm to all living things is morally relevant. And people should care about both. It's not that it is wrong to focus on animal welfare when humans are suffering. It's that there cannot to a moral

Would you be surprised to hear that a study found that research subjects were more upset by stories of a dog beaten by a baseball bat than of an adult similarly beaten? Or that other researchers found that if forced to choose, 40 percent of people would save their pet dog over a foreign tourist.

Why do you think many people are more empathetic toward the suffering of animals than that of people? In your opinion, is it wrong to focus on animal welfare when humans are suffering? Why do you think so?

---

The amount of cruelty in the world is staggering. Many millions of living things, human and animal, are made to suffer at the hands of others daily. It makes no sense to say that harm to animals is less important than harm to people, because there is no way to find a characteristic of people that makes them more important in a moral calculus than animals.

What morally-relevant characteristic do humans have that animals don't? Intelligence?  No, because some animals are smarter than some humans (e.g., a chimp has more intelligence than a newborn baby). Self-awareness? Animals are self aware. Ability to know right from wrong? Many experiments show a moral sense in some animal species.

The list goes on. There is really no morally-relevant characteristic that decides what is more important: human or animal suffering.

That means all harm to all living things is morally relevant. And people should care about both. It's not that it is wrong to focus on animal welfare when humans are suffering. It's that there cannot to a moral defense of such a view that i

The list goes on. There is really no morally-relevant characteristic that decides what is more important: human or animal suffering.

Is It Wrong to Focus on Animal Welfare When Humans Are Suffering?

Would you be surprised to hear that a study found that research subjects were more upset by stories of a dog beaten by a baseball bat than of an adult similarly beaten? Or that other researchers found that if forced to choose, 40 percent of people would save their pet dog over a foreign tourist.

Why do you think many people are more empathetic toward the suffering of animals than that of people? In your opinion, is it wrong to focus on animal welfare when humans are suffering? Why do you think so?

---

The amount of cruelty in the world is staggering. Many millions of living things, human and animal, are made to suffer at the hands of others daily. It makes no sense to say that harm to animals is less important than harm to people, because there is no way to find a characteristic of people that makes them more important in a moral calculus than animals.

What morally-relevant characteristic do humans have that animals don't? Intelligence?  No, because some animals are smarter than some humans (e.g., a chimp has more intelligence than a newborn baby). Self-awareness? Animals are self aware. Ability to know right from wrong? Many experiments show a moral sense in some animal species.

The list goes on. There is really no morally-relevant characteristic that decides what is more important: human or animal suffering.

That means all harm to all living things is morally relevant. And people should care about both. It's not that it is wrong to focus on animal welfare when humans are suffering. It's that there cannot to a moral defense of such a view that is neither circular nor specious. It must simply be a matter of personal preference -- and that is okay. Some will be more

Is It Wrong to Focus on Animal Welfare When Humans Are Suffering?

Would you be surprised to hear that a study found that research subjects were more upset by stories of a dog beaten by a baseball bat than of an adult similarly beaten? Or that other researchers found that if forced to choose, 40 percent of people would save their pet dog over a foreign tourist.

Why do you think many people are more empathetic toward the suffering of animals than that of people? In your opinion, is it wrong to focus on animal welfare when humans are suffering? Why do you think so?

What morally-relevant characteristic do humans have that animals don't? Intelligence?  No, because some animals are smarter than some humans (e.g., a chimp has more intelligence than a newborn baby). Self-awareness? Animals are self aware. Ability to know right from wrong? Many experiments show a moral sense in some animal species.

The list goes on. There is really no morally-relevant characteristic that decides what is more important: human or animal suffering.

That means all harm to all living things is morally relevant. And people should care about both. It's not that it is wrong to focus on animal welfare when humans are suffering. It's that there cannot to a moral defense of such a view that is neither circular nor specious. It must simply be a matter of personal preference -- and that is okay. Some will be more moved by animal sufferin

Is It Wrong to Focus on Animal Welfare When Humans Are Suffering?

Would you be surprised to hear that a study found that research subjects were more upset by stories of a dog beaten by a baseball bat than of an adult similarly beaten? Or that other researchers found that if forced to choose, 40 percent of people would save their pet dog over a foreign tourist.

Why do you think many people are more empathetic toward the suffering of animals than that of people? In your opinion, is it wrong to focus on animal welfare when humans are suffering? Why do you think so?

Why do you think many people are more empathetic toward the suffering of animals than that of people? In your opinion, is it wrong to focus on animal welfare when humans are suffering? Why do you think so?

---

The amount of cruelty in the world is staggering. Many millions of living things, human and animal, are made to suffer at the hands of others daily. It makes no sense to say that harm to animals is less important than harm to people, because there is no way to find a characteristic of people that makes them more important in a moral calculus than animals.

What morally-relevant characteristic do humans have that animals don't? Intelligence?  No, because some animals are smarter than some humans (e.g., a chimp has more intelligence than a newborn baby). Self-awareness? Animals are self aware. Ability to know right from wrong? Many experiments show a moral sense in some animal species.

The list goes on. There is really no morally-relevant characteristic that decides what is more important: human or animal suffering.

That means all harm to all living things is morally relevant. And people should care about both. It's not that it is wrong to focus on animal welfare when humans are suffering. It's that there cannot to a moral defense of such a view that is neither circular nor specious. It must simply be a matter of personal preference -- and that is okay. Some will be more moved by animal suffering than human, and vice-ve

What morally-relevant characteristic do humans have that animals don't? Intelligence?  No, because some animals are smarter than some humans (e.g., a chimp has more intelligence than a newborn baby). Self-awareness? Animals are self aware. Ability to know right from wrong? Many experiments show a moral sense in some animal species.

The list goes on. There is really no morally-relevant characteristic that decides what is more important: human or animal suffering.

That means all harm to all living things is morally relevant. And people should care about both. It's not that it is wrong to focus on animal welfare when humans are suffering. It's that there cannot to a moral defense of such a view that is neither circular nor specious. It must simply be a matter of personal preference -- and that is okay. Some will be more moved by animal suffering than human, and vice-versa. What is imprtant is

Is It Wrong to Focus on Animal Welfare When Humans Are Suffering?

Would you be surprised to hear that a study found that research subjects were more upset by stories of a dog beaten by a baseball bat than of an adult similarly beaten? Or that other researchers found that if forced to choose, 40 percent of people would save their pet dog over a foreign tourist.

Why do you think many people are more empathetic toward the suffering of animals than that of people? In your opinion, is it wrong to focus on animal welfare when humans are suffering? Why do you think so?

It makes no sense to say that harm to animals is less important than harm to people, because there is no way to find a characteristic of people that makes them more important in a moral calculus than animals.

What morally-relevant characteristic do humans have that animals don't? Intelligence?  No, because some animals are smarter than some humans (e.g., a chimp has more intelligence than a newborn baby). Self-awareness? Animals are self aware. Ability to know right from wrong? Many experiments show a moral sense in some animal species.

The list goes on. There is really no morally-relevant characteristic that decides what is more important: human or animal suffering.

That means all harm to all living things is morally relevant. And people should care about both. It's not that it is wrong to focus on animal welfare when humans are suffering. It's that there cannot to a moral defense of such a view that is neither circular nor specious. It must simply be a matter of personal preference -- and that is okay. Some will be more moved by animal suffering than human, and vice-versa. What is imprtant is that we fight to end this

Is It Wrong to Focus on Animal Welfare When Humans Are Suffering?

Would you be surprised to hear that a study found that research subjects were more upset by stories of a dog beaten by a baseball bat than of an adult similarly beaten? Or that other researchers found that if forced to choose, 40 percent of people would save their pet dog over a foreign tourist.

Why do you think many people are more empathetic toward the suffering of animals than that of people? In your opinion, is it wrong to focus on animal welfare when humans are suffering? Why do you think so?

Would you be surprised to hear that a study found that research subjects were more upset by stories of a dog beaten by a baseball bat than of an adult similarly beaten? Or that other researchers found that if forced to choose, 40 percent of people would save their pet dog over a foreign tourist.

Why do you think many people are more empathetic toward the suffering of animals than that of people? In your opinion, is it wrong to focus on animal welfare when humans are suffering? Why do you think so?

---

The amount of cruelty in the world is staggering. Many millions of living things, human and animal, are made to suffer at the hands of others daily. It makes no sense to say that harm to animals is less important than harm to people, because there is no way to find a characteristic of people that makes them more important in a moral calculus than animals.

What morally-relevant characteristic do humans have that animals don't? Intelligence?  No, because some animals are smarter than some humans (e.g., a chimp has more intelligence than a newborn baby). Self-awareness? Animals are self aware. Ability to know right from wrong? Many experiments show a moral sense in some animal species.

The list goes on. There is really no morally-relevant characteristic that decides what is more important: human or animal suffering.

That means all harm to all living things is morally relevant. And people should care about both. It's not that it is wrong to focus on animal welfare when humans are suffering. It's that there cannot to a moral defense of such a view that is neither circular nor specious. It must simply be a matter of personal preference -- and that is okay. Some will be more moved by animal suffering than human, and vice-versa. What is imprtant is that we fight to end this, whatever its victimes

Why do you think many people are more empathetic toward the suffering of animals than that of people? In your opinion, is it wrong to focus on animal welfare when humans are suffering? Why do you think so?

The amount of cruelty in the world is staggering. Many millions of living things, human and animal, are made to suffer at the hands of others daily. It makes no sense to say that harm to animals is less important than harm to people, because there is no way to find a characteristic of people that makes them more important in a moral calculus than animals.

What morally-relevant characteristic do humans have that animals don't? Intelligence?  No, because some animals are smarter than some humans (e.g., a chimp has more intelligence than a newborn baby). Self-awareness? Animals are self aware. Ability to know right from wrong? Many experiments show a moral sense in some animal species.

The list goes on. There is really no morally-relevant characteristic that decides what is more important: human or animal suffering.

That means all harm to all living things is morally relevant. And people should care about both. It's not that it is wrong to focus on animal welfare when humans are suffering. It's that there cannot to a moral defense of such a view that is neither circular nor specious. It must simply be a matter of personal preference -- and that is okay. Some will be more moved by animal suffering than human, and vice-versa. What is important is that we fight to end this, whether the victims are human or anima.

Is It Wrong to Focus on Animal Welfare When Humans Are Suffering?

Would you be surprised to hear that a study found that research subjects were more upset by stories of a dog beaten by a baseball bat than of an adult similarly beaten? Or that other researchers found that if forced to choose, 40 percent of people would save their pet dog over a foreign tourist.

The list goes on. There is really no morally-relevant characteristic that decides what is more important: human or animal suffering.

That means all harm to all living things is morally relevant. And people should care about both. It's not that it is wrong to focus on animal welfare when humans are suffering. It's that there cannot to a moral defense of such a view that is neither circular nor specious. It must simply be a matter of personal preference -- and that is okay. Some will be more moved by animal suffering than human, and vice-versa. 

What is important is that we fight to end needless sufferi, whether the victims are human or animal.

Is It Wrong to Focus on Animal Welfare When Humans Are Suffering?

Would you be surprised to hear that a study found that research subjects were more upset by stories of a dog beaten by a baseball bat than of an adult similarly beaten? Or that other researchers found that if forced to choose, 40 percent of people would save their pet dog over a foreign tourist.

Why do you think many people are more empathetic toward the suffering of animals than that of people? In your opinion, is it wrong to focus on animal welfare when humans are suffering? Why do you think so?

---

The amount of cruelty in the world is staggering. Many millions of living things, human and animal, are made to suffer at the hands of others daily. It makes no sense to say that harm to animals is less important than harm to people, because there is no way to find a characteristic of people that makes them more important in a moral calculus than animals.

What morally-relevant characteristic do humans have that animals don't? Intelligence?
